questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with fever, arthralgia, rash, and fatigue that began 10 days after completing a course of ceftriaxone for a urinary tract infection. Physical examination reveals a diffuse maculopapular rash, tender lymphadenopathy, and mild joint swelling. Laboratory results show: Elevated ESR and CRP Decreased C3 and C4 complement levels Mild proteinuria and hematuria No peripheral eosinophilia Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serum sickness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serum sickness is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition and complement activation, often triggered by drugs like ceftriaxone, leading to systemic symptoms such as fever, rash, and arthralgia.
  • ➤ Serum sickness
  • ➤ Type III hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with generalized muscle weakness and fatigue that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She also reports diplopia and ptosis. Initial testing reveals a negative serum anti-AChR antibody test. Further investigations reveal the presence of anti-MuSK antibodies. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of anti-MuSK antibodies excludes the possibility of anti-AChR antibodies in other patients.

options.label: B
options.text: Anti-MuSK antibodies are commonly found in patients with weakness confined to ocular muscles.

options.label: C
options.text: Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).

options.label: D
options.text: The severity of myasthenia gravis correlates directly with the measured level of anti-AChR antibodies.

questions.correct_answer: C. Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR antibodies may have anti-MuSK antibodies . These antibodies play a significant role in the clustering of acetylcholine receptors and are critical for diagnosing antibody-negative MG.
  • ➤ Patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR antibodies may have anti-MuSK antibodies .
  • ➤ generalized MG
  • ➤ anti-MuSK antibodies
  • ➤ These antibodies play a significant role in the clustering of acetylcholine receptors and are critical for diagnosing antibody-negative MG.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath. Echocardiography reveals mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy. Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a chronic consequence of acute rheumatic fever , characterized by valvular damage and granulomatous changes such as Aschoff bodies .

  • ➤ acute rheumatic fever
  • ➤ valvular damage
  • ➤ granulomatous changes

  • ➤ It most frequently affects the mitral valve , leading to mitral stenosis .

  • ➤ mitral stenosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent epistaxis and easy bruising. Laboratory tests show a prolonged bleeding time but normal platelet count. A peripheral blood smear shows large platelets. A platelet aggregation study reveals an abnormal response to ristocetin but a normal response to ADP and collagen. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely causing her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glycoprotein Ib/IX

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX, which plays a critical role in platelet adhesion to von Willebrand factor. It is characterized by large platelets, prolonged bleeding time, and defective platelet aggregation in response to ristocetin.
  • ➤ Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX, which plays a critical role in platelet adhesion to von Willebrand factor.
  • ➤ It is characterized by large platelets, prolonged bleeding time, and defective platelet aggregation in response to ristocetin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of recurrent epigastric pain and dyspepsia undergoes an upper GI endoscopy, revealing gastric mucosal inflammation with a possible ulcer. A biopsy is taken, and the image shows the result of a special stain used to identify the organism involved. Which of the following stains is most likely depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Warthin-Starry silver stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Warthin-Starry stain is a silver stain used to detect H. pylori , which appears as spiral-shaped, dark-staining bacteria. This stain is crucial in diagnosing H. pylori-related gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.
  • ➤ The Warthin-Starry stain is a silver stain used to detect H. pylori , which appears as spiral-shaped, dark-staining bacteria.
  • ➤ H. pylori
  • ➤ This stain is crucial in diagnosing H. pylori-related gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old gardener presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of painless nodular lesions on his left forearm. He recalls pricking his hand on a thorn while trimming rose bushes 3 weeks ago. The lesions began as a small papule on his hand and have since spread proximally along the forearm in a linear pattern. He denies fever, chills, or systemic symptoms. The image of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Itraconazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection often associated with traumatic inoculation during gardening. The typical presentation includes nodular lesions spreading along lymphatics, and itraconazole is the first-line treatment for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.
  • ➤ Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection often associated with traumatic inoculation during gardening.
  • ➤ The typical presentation includes nodular lesions spreading along lymphatics, and itraconazole is the first-line treatment for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS-P score of a patient brought into the ER with history of fall from a motorcycle. He is just making incomprehensible sounds, has a completely flexed posture and only opens his eyes to knuckle pressure. On examination, right pupil is unreactive to light:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is diagnosed with persistent atrial fibrillation. She is prescribed an antiarrhythmic drug that selectively prolongs the action potential by blocking delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3. The drug has no significant effects on sodium or calcium channels, nor does it act on beta-adrenergic receptors. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to her?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dofetilide is a pure Class III antiarrhythmic drug that prolongs the action potential by selectively blocking the delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. It does not have effects on sodium or calcium channels or adrenergic receptors, distinguishing it from other Class III agents.
  • ➤ Dofetilide is a pure Class III antiarrhythmic drug that prolongs the action potential by selectively blocking the delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential.
  • ➤ It does not have effects on sodium or calcium channels or adrenergic receptors, distinguishing it from other Class III agents.
